sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/common/const.message: In the future, we probably need to state and handle app inter-dependencies in a formal way. Then use this to drive the order of app re-apply. For now this is ok as the platform app will always be applied first if multiple apps need to be applied. stx-monitor also has a dependency on the platform app. This might need to be added to this list as well.

Even though multiple apps may have the need reapply flag set not all of them are in a state where they can be applied. What happens when both stx-openstack and platform-integ-apps need to be applied after controller-1 unlock (for example) is that platform-integ-apps waits for controller-1 services to become available while stx-openstack starts applying.

I added only the mechanism to guard against multiple apps being applied at the same time if they are all in a can-be-applied state.

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/conductor/ma.message: This is doing an evaluation - not necessarily a reapply.
Apply one app at a time.
Prevent re-apply if any other apply is in progress. If platform-integ-apps needs to be re-applied but stx-openstack apply is in progress it times out waiting for a lock.
Skip looking for a specific task value here because the test is not reliable: it ignores "Rebooting" and probably many other values as well when apps shouldn't be applied.
how are we ensuring that other_app is not the app which needs reapply?  (i.e.Does it also need to check other_app.app_name != app_name?)

Let's say other_app = app_name. Can this apply in progress be caused by the current flag being raised? No, because the flag is cleared before re-apply.

Then flag raised means overrides have changed while app apply was in progress for the old (different) overrides. In this case the app needs to be re-applied as soon as possible.

https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/reference/api-microversion-history.html#id35

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Not sure how we've been handling this here, but I just wanted to point out we stopped using DocImpact elsewhere. This triggers the creation of a bug for openstack-manuals. That was useful when there was an actual docs team that would pick them up and incorporate doc changes, but now that that team is pretty much gone and most docs are in-tree, it's usually easier to not use this and just include the documentation updates with the patch.

That said, it may still be useful if we need a bug to track any follow on documentation activity that the glance team is going to have to do, so it may still be useful.

storlets/sbus/datagram.py.message: nit: I wonder if we really need the deep copy here.

This is required, because we don't like to include 'type' key in original storlets_metadata, and only add it we get Metadata info via metadata property.

If we don't have this deepcopy, storlets_metadata is updated to have type key after we call its metadata property, which I'm afraid seems very strange behavior.

tests/unit/sbus/test_datagram.py.message:
ah... this is missing the context `from_metadata_dict` because the first arg 1 is not a dict just a fileno.

Strictly, it should be like "fileno": 1 in the dict?

I agree that this name is confusing.

However, I'm afraid that it is not a good idea to have fileno inside dict.
In sbus layer we always get a list of fileno and a list of metadata independently, and placing fd inside metadata cause the following redundant process.
 1. Get fileno and its metadata independently from sbus c lib
 2. Merge fileno into metadata in build_datagram
 3. Then get fileno from metadata here

please have a look at subsequent patch, where I revert the change in args with fixing this confusing funcname.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/676962/

openvswitch/Dockerfile.ubuntu_bionic-dpd.message:
I strongly recommend not to tie the container image to a particular kernel version. Doing this requires to run the very same kernel on the host OS and in the container image, i.e., keeping both in sync. This is typically not wanted. Instead, I recommend to disable all kernel dependend functionality in the DPDK source build, which only affects the KNI interface and UIO drivers.

Moreover, it might be useful to add a march flag to control the optimizations GCC applies. We ran into issues with images built on a Haswell CPU crashing on SandyBridge CPUs.

We did work on this some time ago but abandoned it in favor of the distribution provided images. Still, if we decide to add this functionality to the Dockerfile, please see this file (lines 42-45):

http://paste.openstack.org/show/754706/
I agree, will make the required correction as per the reference you provided. Thanks

This ADD command will work regardless of whether the patch files exist or not, but for that we must put the name of any one valid file. As we know Dockerfile.ubuntu_bionic-dpdk must always be there (this being the file via docker build is being run) so I used it. Later on I remove it as well so that it is not part of the image eventually
this will need to be a param, to allow people to build using alternative sources.

let's not overengineer this if not needed, but what if you need to apply multiple patches? Is that a valid use case for you? If so, changing the if-statements to for-loops would be more flexible.

I thought about it but as creating a patch is within our control, the user can combine all those patches and create a single patch for complete folder structure. Also as of now we have been using single patch file only. So I would suggest to keep the current implementation..... :) But if you want then I can do the changes as required....

Maybe we can't assume any user provided DPDK_SRC_URL contains the resource "dpdk-${DPDK_SRC_COMPILE_VERSION}.tar.xz".

pls see above comment

same as above
Why are we adding the dockerfile and then removing it below?

Actually docker doesn't support copying a file conditionally so to overcome this, it is a workaround/hack. This ADD command will work regardless of whether the patch files exist or not, but for that we must put the name of any one valid file. As we know Dockerfile.ubuntu_bionic-dpdk must always be there (this being the file via docker build is being run) so I used it. Later on it is removed because we don't want it to be a part of the image eventually.
Can you explain why we are doing this (in comments)? There is no value in having these exposed at runtime?
These are some of the DPDK compile time flags which we want to be set as 'no' so as not to compile kernel modules.

maybe just to complement Deepak's answer (and a proposal for a comment in this Dockerfile): this disables build-time dependencies to a specific kernel version. By design, these features are kernel dependent and must be run on the same kernel they were built against. However, the image will later run on a different kernel most likely.

storlets/sbus/datagram.py.message:
This looks a little weird because the expected_fd_types is generated by given_fd_types and get_optional_fd_types doesn't use the actual list, just nothing or length of given_fd_types.

It seems, given_fd_types is also incomprehensible, maybe?

If we want to check the optional list strictly, I bet to implement _check_optional_fd_types, instead, then pass the rest of given fds then check the type is in expected ones.

> This looks a little weird because the expected_fd_types is generated by given_fd_types and ...

I selected current option because of the following points.

1. 
If we have another method to validate optional fds, we can not easily show the list of whole fds. I believe showing whole list can make it easier to debug incorrect fd list.

2.
The reason why we currently pass given_fd_types is that we need the length of fds to calculate the number of extra input fds.
IMO this should be replaced by parameters (like extra_input_num, extra_output_num), which makes much more sense to have single validation here, but now I'll leave it for future work at the moment.

My point is that we don't have to check everything in the parent class. i.e. the inherited child class may assert the optional args by overriding this method. (or add general _check_optional_fd_types called by this method).

we can transfer the responsibility to the child class.

puppet-manifests/src/modules/platform/ma.message: Are you sure =~ works in this case? Shouldn't the pattern on the right side be something like "${disk_path}-part\d+"?

Yes, I check with this way

On storage node
$ ceph osd create
$ uuidgen
Add the generated osd id and uuid in /tmp/puppet/host.yaml
with a not used disk /dev/disk/by-parth//dev/disk/by-path/pci-0000:00:17.0-ata-6.0-part1 for data path, and also add journal disk path

puppet apply --debug --trace --modulepath /usr/share/puppet/modules:/usr/share/openstack-puppet/modules storage.pp

And also check this link
https://puppet.com/docs/puppet/5.3/lang_expressions.html#regex-or-data-type-match

It clarify that the right operand could be "a stringified regular expression"

=~ (regex or data type match)
Resolves to true if the left operand matches the right operand. “Match” can mean two different things, depending on what the right operand is.

This operator is non-transitive with regard to data types. The right operand must be one of:

A regular expression (like /^[<>=]{7}/)
A stringified regular expression — that is, a string that represents a regular expression, like "^[<>=]{7}"
A data type (like Integer[1,10])

I looked at the reference link before posting my 1st comment.

My point was you are using a plain string as the right operator that was supposed to be a stringified regular expression. This means that, for example, all "." in the ${disk_path} will match any character at the corresponding index in ${journal_path}.

Using =~ here is just a hack to check $disk_path is a prefix of $journal_path.
Add comment this branch is for collocated journal.

So I'll take a (very) high-level stab at it:

TIS_VERSION has been used as the global counter for tracking installed bits.  This changes to the actual package version and is no longer global.  It gets handled similar to existing upstream packages from e.g. CentOS that are unmodified and have no TIS_VERSION.
I think we need to skip this for now and just add the bits required to make PBR happy even for non-Python projects.
Please explain this line

"Split git repos according to versioning of deliverables, i.e. each repo has a single version and all deliverables from that repo will share that version."

This is moving cgts-client into its own repo comes in, so it can be released and installed separately from everything else, for example.  In reality that is the driver, this versioning spec is to help support that in a consistent way across StarlingX.

I don't think this is an accurate statement. Each package has its own independent version. In most cases, this version is a combination of a Version that's defined in the package's spec file and the TIS_PATCH_VERSION value for that package.
This is an over simplification. This implies each repo can be independently delivered. It cannot and getting there would be much more then versioning.

This is a very important point. Under this proposal, every package within a repo would now have the same version. Without restructuring, an update to any package in the integ repo, for example, would upversion all packages in that repo.

> This is a very important point. Under this proposal, every package
 > within a repo would now have the same version. Without

It will not affect all packages at once when new versioning is supported. I think we can add new versioning support first. If TIS_PATCH_VER is defined in build_srpm.data, it still uses the old versioning. Then, we can remove TIS_PATCH_VER and split the repo one-by-one.

reference/runtimes/ussuri.rst.message: I don't know why this needs to be mentioned in the supported runtimes document. Projects are free to test with additional runtimes and in some cases (like Tempest and some of its plugin projects) may have a strong need to do so. This document is more about what versions users/deployers of the Ussuri release of OpenStack can expect to work. The need for 2.7/3.5 in Tempest is directly related to previous releases and not Ussuri, so the more notes and caveats we add here the more confusing we'll make it for them.

This document is about what Python runtimes *all* Python-based deliverables must support. Specific projects can (and sometimes must) support other runtimes too, but this is not the place to note every possible addition for random deliverables. They can do that in their own project documentation.

can we add the python older versions (py27 and py3.5) for Tempest and its plugins explicitly as we discussed on IRC

I am adding the same for py3.5 in Train runtime - https://review.opendev.org/#/c/680407/1/reference/runtimes/train.rst

agree for OpenStack services officially supported python version but if you think from Tempest and its plugins's users perspective they should not be in an impression that older python version which are not listed in this doc are not officially supported by Tempest and plugins. 

Tempest and its plugins are branchless so we cannot associated them with a particular release. Any Tempest version has a set of supported release[1] not just single release support. If we see that from user point of view, they can use Tempest against any of the supported release.

This means few older python version are also *officially supported* (which is what this doc about) by Tempest and its plugins. and if we mentioned that as NOTE here will make Tempest and its plugins's users very clear about what all python version officially supported. 


[1] https://docs.openstack.org/releasenotes/tempest/v21.0.0.html#prelude
I have to agree with Jeremy on this. We just need a simple, clear, and direct message so our users know what to expect (and can go back in the future and know what was expected for an older release).

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Please summarize what the patch does in the title, then move "Updating per conversation with icey" to the commit message body as some context.

The reason for this change is that if we have problems later and browse the commits looking for the offending one, we would see "Updating per conversation with icey" and we wouldn't have any idea of what that patch does, we would need to open it individually and read it in detail.

specs/train/approved/policy-d-override.r.message:
I know that this was mentioned elsewhere but I think we'll have a required to inject things like the UUID of the service domain/admin domain or suchlike.

I think the initial implementation needs to cover this - a) by providing a standard set of keys that can be used in policy overrides and b) supporting .j2 extensions for files in the resource zip which get rendered and then validated rather than just validated.

I had thought about this, and it's relatively easy to add; I just wasn't sure how that might be used.

The 'project_id', 'user_id' and 'domain_id' are all available in the rules as %(project_id)s for example, no templating needed.  So I was curious about where the template vars would come from? e.g. context or passed in from the charm?

Forgive me if I've missed this detail, but I'm not seeing the info here:

Starting with which version combination of OpenStack + Ubuntu is this work to be implemented?

It appeared, AFAICT, in the ocata release of oslo.policy, and I picked queens as that's the version that ships with Bionic, and it was two OpenStack cycles to allow projects to implement the Enforcer from oslo.policy.  Each OpenStack project will need to use oslo.policy's Enforcer to make it work.  I'm checking each project at queens to make sure that it's supported before implementing it in the respective charm.

So, happy to push it back to Xenial as that should be orthogonal to the OpenStack version.
If the dependencies are satisfied on Xenial-Queens, and if we were already developing this for Bionic-Queens, then I would be +1 on Xenial-Queens scope for this feature.
If its possible, xenial-queens would be a more appropriate start target version. Because xenial was the only available version at the queens release, this is the combination that is mostly used.

Ah, it's right down the bottom of the section.  Possibly not the best place for it.  I can move it up?  queens-bionic is currently targetted as the earliest version, due to queens being the first version of oslo.policy that supports overrides, and bionic, as it's queens LTS release.

However, I saw some chatter about xenial?  We could make it xenial-queens instead?
